abstract.p: Report by Thomson Venture Economics and National Venture Capital Association shows that annualized returns of private equity funds over last 20 years slipped below 15 percent minimum expected by most venture capital investors (S)

block.p: The annualized returns of private equity funds over the last 20 years have slipped below the 15 percent minimum expected by most venture capital investors, according to Jesse Reyes, vice president of Thomson Venture Economics.
''While the final outcome may ultimately redeem these investments,'' he said, ''it does appear that it will be an uphill climb to meet investor expectations.''

The annualized returns of private equity funds over the last 20 years have slipped below the 15 percent minimum expected by most venture capital investors, according to Jesse Reyes, vice president of Thomson Venture Economics.
''While the final outcome may ultimately redeem these investments,'' he said, ''it does appear that it will be an uphill climb to meet investor expectations.''

A new report by Thomson Venture Economics and the National Venture Capital Association found that over the 12 months through last September, the funds lost 22.3 percent. The third quarter was the seventh consecutive quarter of net declines for private equity funds, Mr. Reyes said.
Funds that started in the last three years have had problems, the report said, because the value of their portfolio companies has fallen, and the demand for such investments has been slack.
''It will likely take several years for short-term private equity performance to return back to normal levels,'' he said.
